awd_titl_txt: Ground-Based Magnetometer Array Planning Workshop; Greenbelt, Maryland; May 5-6, 2016
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a short-term (less than one-year) effort to organize and plan a workshop to bring together U.S. scientists and lead personnel who are operating individual ground-based magnetometer arrays.  The purpose is to explore efficiencies in the management of these arrays and optimize resources by designing a shared framework for integrated data storage, archiving, dissemination, and high-level data products.  Since these independent arrays observe different portions of Earth's space environment (Earth-space), their further development and integration has potential for providing a powerful tool for synthesizing information about its global dynamics. The planned shared framework will be separate from the scientific research, proposed and performed by individual investigator teams, and thus will provide much needed continuity for funding the instrumentation and data distribution during lapses in individual research funding. The effects of these interruptions are compounded because observations from these magnetometer arrays are used by the broader research community and in international collaborations, in addition to their use in scientific research by the magnetometer teams, themselves.  Efficiencies in the operation and maintenance of ground-based magnetometer arrays as well as in the development of new global high-level data products will strengthen and improve a valuable U.S. infrastructure for exploring Earth-space and understanding its long-term evolution. 

Ground-based magnetometers make use of signatures in the Earth's magnetic field to explore and understand Earth-space.  These signatures provide information about ionospheric currents associated with geomagnetic storms and substorms, the magnetosphere's response to interplanetary shocks, the reconfiguration of currents and convection as the solar wind driving changes, and the propagation of energy through Earth-space carried by long-period plasma waves.   They provide the longest record of Earth-space observations and thus are key to our understanding of long-term variations in that environment.  Magnetometer arrays are supported and maintained by countries all over the world so the US arrays contribute valuable information to synthesizing an understanding of the global dynamics in Earth-space. Efficiencies in operations and maintenance of these arrays are important to enable the continuing support and further development of this valuable national observing capability.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Grant AGS-1639587 was awarded to Augsburg College to cover expenses related to organizing and leading a planning workshop for U.S. scientists who operate ground-based magnetometer arrays and/or use data from them in their research in geospace sciences, to covering travel expenses of participants, and preparing and publishing a report on the workshop to NSF.  Dr. Mark Engebretson, Professor Emeritus of Physics at Augsburg College, Minneapolis, MN, and Dr. Eftyhia Zesta, Chief of the Geospace Physics Laboratory, Heliospheric Physics Division, NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD, were invited to lead these efforts. 

Ground-based magnetometers, which make use of signatures in Earth’s magnetic fields, provide the longest record of Earth-space observations, and continue to be an integral part of many observational studies of the upper atmosphere, ionosphere, and magnetosphere.  The purpose of the workshop was to explore efficiencies in the management of these arrays and transitions toward a shared framework for integrated data storage, archiving, dissemination, and production of higher-level data products.

This workshop took place May 5 and 6, 2016 at the Greenbelt Marriott Hotel, Greenbelt, MD.  Attendees included scientists and engineers representing each of the major ground magnetometer networks funded by NSF’s Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences Division, NSF’s Office of Polar Programs, NASA, and the U.S. Geological Survey, as well as several scientists who make extensive use of ground magnetometer data and NSF-AGS personnel. 

After substantial community consultation, a 40-page report on this workshop was presented to Dr. John Meriwether, Jr., Program Director for Geospace Facilities in the Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences Division at NSF on February 8, 2017.   Drs. Engebretson and Zesta also prepared a condensed and updated version of the report, which was published in Space Weather in November 2017.  Two followup workshops were also held, and these efforts have led to continuing community efforts to upgrade array support, management, communication, and production of higher-level data products.
